rows.text_1:
**Giving instructions that work**
Even the best behaved children only follow instructions about 50% of the time.

*How* we give instructions can make things more peaceful and calm at home.

Negative instructions like, “Don’t do that!” can make children (and us) feel bad.

Children are more likely to follow an instruction when it is worded in a positive way.
rows.media_title: **How will it help me and my family?**
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them ‘stop fighting’ or ‘stop playing with your food’, they don’t know what we DO want them to do.  

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

rows.text_1: Let’s see how {F1_MOTHER} gives instructions that work to {F1_DAUGHTER_2}:

rows.text_2: {F1_DAUGHTER_2} is playing with the blocks on the floor.

**{F1_MOTHER}**: “It is nice to see you playing quietly with the blocks while I clear up after dinner, {F1_DAUGHTER_2}. In 3 minutes, you will need to pack away the blocks, so we can start getting ready for bed.”
**{F1_DAUGHTER_2}**: “Okay, {F1_MOTHER}.”

*3 minutes later*
**{F1_MOTHER}**: “3 minutes is over, {F1_DAUGHTER_2}. Please pack away your blocks.”
**{F1_DAUGHTER_2}**: “Okay.”

**{F1_MOTHER}**: “Thank you very much for packing away the blocks when I asked you, {F1_DAUGHTER_2}. Because you listened so well, I will read you an extra story before bed.”
**{F1_DAUGHTER_2}**: “Yay!”**{F1_MOTHER}**: “Once upon a time…”

rows.text_1:
Let’s look at another family to see how positive instructions can even help to prevent misbehaviour before it starts! 

{F2_GRANDFATHER} is working in the garden while his granddaughter, {F2_DAUGHTER_3} and grandson, {F2_SON_8} are playing with a ball:

rows.text_2:
{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Give it back to me!

{F2_SON_8}: But I want it!
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: {F2_DAUGHTER_3} and {F2_SON_8} come and help me plant these vegetables together.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: Thank you for coming to help me. We are going to grow lots of vegetables together.

rows.text_1: Let’s reflect on what {F2_GRANDFATHER} did here.
rows.quiz_1_question: **What would have happened if {F2_GRANDFATHER} had not paid attention to the children?**
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: They would have started to argue
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Yes, the situation between the children would have gotten out of hand.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: They could have hurt each other in the argument
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Yes, children could have gotten so upset that they would have hurt each other.
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: {F2_GRANDFATHER} would have had to stop working in the garden
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Yes, if {F2_GRANDFATHER} had kept quiet, he would have lost more time trying to resolve the conflict.
rows.quiz_2_question: **What does {F2_GRANDFATHER} do to prevent the argument from getting out of hand?**
rows.quiz_2_option_1_text: He draw their attention away from the problem
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: That’s right. He quickly intervenes to distract them, and gives a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.
rows.quiz_2_option_2_text: He involves them in a positive activity
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: That’s right. He quickly intervenes to distract them, and gives a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.
rows.quiz_2_option_3_text: He praises the children for their positive behaviour
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: That’s right. He gives a positive instruction to redirect them, and praises them for their positive behaviour.

rows.text_1: Here are three tips on how to give positive instructions that work:
rows.section_1_text:
**BE SPECIFIC**
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
Connect to them first, so they are more likely to listen.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Use your child’s name to get your child’s attention. Go down to their level. Get their eye contact.
Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: “Please take your shoes off when you come inside, {...}.”
rows.section_2_text:
**BE REALISTIC**
Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do. 
Giving a transition warning helps!
rows.section_2_extra_text:
It can be difficult for your child to remember many instructions, so only give one at a time!
If possible, give a transition warning. For example: “In 3 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.”
rows.section_3_text:
**BE POSITIVE**
Use positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of “Don’t shout,” say “Talk in a quiet voice.”
Praise your child for following your instruction.
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.
Praise, praise, praise! Make sure you praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction.
Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

rows.text_2: Here are some child behaviours that many parents find challenging.

rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Pay attention to your child and give a positive instruction to redirect them towards a positive behaviour, like helping you with something or playing a different game.

rows.text_1:
Try giving your child specific, realistic, and positive instructions. 

Remember to give one instruction at a time and praise them. This will help your child to follow your instructions.
rows.media_title: How it helped a parent like you:
rows.media_transcript:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learned about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say “please **do** this” instead of “**don’t** do this.” 
My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My child said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.
